repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Problem: The codelens module displays lenses as virtual text. Because extmarks are set in the local display_line_lenses function, this cannot be changed directly. (Per igorlfs, this would close https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33923) Proposed solution: Create a display option in the codelens module that allows configuring which extmarks are set. Add code to support virtual lines. Questions: - ~~Is this the best design pattern to achieve this goal? I based it on vim.lsp.log.get_level() and set_level(). I wanted to avoid exposing more of the module's internals in the name of achieving a simple end result~~ - ~~Is CodeLensDisplay the best naming choice for the opts table?~~ - ~~Is the validation/annotation for hl_mode done in the best way? It's a direct copy of what's in the vim.api.keyset.set_extmark annotation, but would also have to be manually edited if the API changed~~

comment_data.body: This makes me thing a callback might fit better. If we are just forwarding parameters to `nvim_buf_set_extmark` that's a signal that maybe the user can define a function that calls `nvim_buf_set_extmark` or whatever.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1938,6 +1938,20 @@ Client:supports_method({method}, {bufnr})           *Client:supports_method()*
 ==============================================================================
 Lua module: vim.lsp.codelens                                    *lsp-codelens*
 
+*vim.lsp.codelens.display.Opts*
+    Display options for lenses
+
+    Fields: ~
+      • {extmark_params}  (`vim.api.keyset.set_extmark`) See

comment_data.body: this is yet another way of configuring stuff. look for existing patterns. we have `vim.foo.config` for various things, that's one way. the other common mechanism is `enable(..., {opts})`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1997,6 +2017,14 @@ save({lenses}, {bufnr}, {client_id})                 *vim.lsp.codelens.save()*
       • {bufnr}      (`integer`)
       • {client_id}  (`integer`)
 
+set_display({opts})                           *vim.lsp.codelens.set_display()*
+    Sets display options for lenses

@@ -1964,6 +1978,12 @@ get({bufnr})                                          *vim.lsp.codelens.get()*
     Return: ~
         (`lsp.CodeLens[]`)
 
+get_display()                                 *vim.lsp.codelens.get_display()*
+    Gets current display options for lenses

comment_data.body: Could use config(), and have a nil opts table return return the current config the way vim.diagnostic does. This would also resolve the comment on get_display()
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1997,6 +2017,14 @@ save({lenses}, {bufnr}, {client_id})                 *vim.lsp.codelens.save()*
       • {bufnr}      (`integer`)
       • {client_id}  (`integer`)
 
+set_display({opts})                           *vim.lsp.codelens.set_display()*
+    Sets display options for lenses

comment_data.body: Can do this like the diagnostic module, where you can either enter a boolean or a callback function. Would save a bunch of guard code.

comment_data.body: This doesn't align with how we configure other LSP features. We had a discussion around high-level configuration in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34659 and it seems like we're still unsure of what the right interface is, but for now I don't think we should add a new way to configure things.

I can understand that, given where the overall state of those discussions is.

What about passing an opt and/or callback directly through codelens.refresh() and codelens.display()? This is in line with how a lot of other LSP functions handle customizable behavior, and also helps with the per-config question because different callbacks can be mapped based on which buf is being attached to (allowing leverage of future buf local config options).
A callback does sound like a better design to me. WDYT @justinmk?
That sounds better, I wasn't feeling good about a new, nested `config` thing. Thanks for the callout @MariaSolOs

Should I make any movement toward allowing the on_codelens client-to-server response handler to be deprecated? Or should I assume that's the interface going forward? 

It calls the display function and is called by the refresh function, so a callback based approach to setting display has to run through it.

Biggest chokepoint for that function is actually testing. Both the LSP spec and codelens spec use it.

Does that need to be decided now, i.e. does it change the shape of this PR? Would prefer to minimize the diff of this PR so we can focus on step 1 before pondering step 2. Feel free to create an issue to track that idea and sketch it out.

> Does that need to be decided now, i.e. does it change the shape of this PR? Would prefer to minimize the diff of this PR so we can focus on step 1 before pondering step 2. Feel free to create an issue to track that idea and sketch it out.

I agree that would be a lot for this PR. I'll make an update focusing on the callback change.

Once that's done, I'd be happy to keep after it. The tracking issue is a good idea.

comment_regular_data.body:
UPDATE:

- ~~In line with vim.lsp.codelens.refresh.Opts, renamed the display opts to vim.lsp.codelens.display.Opts~~
- Added annotations and re-built docs
- ~~Still unsure of how to handle the hl_mode option. An alternative could be to allow for passing in an entire extmark opts table, then letting display_line_lenses add the options it needs to using a table extend. The upside - very extensible and hackable. The downsides - Might be a lot to throw at an inexperienced user, and the errors on a malformed keyset would be brutal~~

> screenshot? > > is there an open issue for this? This is how the virtual line display looks in my setup: No open issue that I'm aware of. But since I had hacked a version of it together for myself, wanted to try building it out.

put the screenshot in the top description :) 

I think the idea makes sense, but the set_display/get_display is probably not the right interface.

Wanted to keep testing simple rather than bloating things with a kitchen sink mentality. But definitely open to feedback there. 

If good to go, I can write up a news entry and remove the draft status.

Added news and removed draft status. Been building my Neovim install from this branch for a week or so without issue.

That said, if there are additional suggestions, happy to address.

Updated based on the discussion above.

The new opts table is based on vim.lsp.ListOpts. Either a boolean can be passed to turn on virtual lines, or a callback can be used for further customization.

Since its future status might not be certain, I avoided drawing attention to the changes in on_codelens. 

Open to additional feedback if needed.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(lsp): display codelens as virtual lines (instead of virtual text)
